intro: Endlicheria zapoteoides, commonly known as the Mexican wild fig, is a small evergreen tree native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It belongs to the Moraceae family, which includes figs and mulberries, and is characterized by its simple, alternate leaves that are usually elliptical in shape. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers that are clustered in inflorescences, followed by small, inedible fruits. It thrives in tropical and subtropical climates, often growing in moist, well-drained soils in forested areas.
